-23- Classic Films

-24- Mainstream Classics

Mainstream classics. Good to have in your vocabulary if you’re a film buff, good for igniting nostalgia.

**** Arsenic and Old Lace
***** Casablanca
**** A Streetcar Named Desire
*** Saturday Night Fever

*** The Girl Next Door
******* Requiem for a Dream
***** A Simple Plan
******* Boys Don’t Cry
******* Starred Up
***** Black Swan
****** Boyhood
***** Kids
*** Irréversible




-26- Dark Psychological Thrillers, Male-Centric

Well-made, classic, extremely entertaining psychological thrillers with dark subject matter, centered around male characters.

******* Fight Club
******* A Clockwork Orange
***** American History X
***** Bad Boys
***** Cool Hand Luke




-27- Action Films with Sci-Fi Roots

Great action films with science fiction roots, plenty of suspense and entertainment. Well-constructed, original mise-en-scene.

***** District 9
***** Arrival
****** Predator
**** Contact
******* Alien
**** Prometheus
**** Aliens
***** Jurassic Park
**** A Quiet Place




-28- Off-Beat, Original Human Dramas

Slightly off-beat, highly original human drama. Slow-paced, but rich in both production and entertainment value.

***** Magnolia
****** 500 Days of Summer
****** Silver Linings Playbook
**** I’m Here (Short)

**** Kontroll
**** The Squid and the Whale

***** Moonrise Kingdom
**** Beginners
***** Hunt for the Wilderpeople

**** Happiness

**** The Florida Project
*** The Big Sick
***** Call Me by Your Name
*** La La Land
******* In the Mood for Love
**** Chungking Express




-29- Quintessential Psychological Thrillers

Quintessential psychological thrillers. High entertainment value, with seminal performances by many great actors.

***** The Machinist
****** The Shining
****** Shutter Island
****** Primal Fear
***** Donnie Darko
**** The Butterfly Effect
****** Being John Malkovich
****** The Departed
***** The Prestige
***** V for Vendetta
***** Killing of a Sacred Deer




-30- Slow-Paced Suburban Dramas

Slow-paced drama about suburban life, usually with a good message. Interesting plots.

**** Stand By Me
***** Pleasantville
**** To Die For
**** Baby It’s You




-31- Excellent Script-Driven Dramas

Excellent scripts, drama, and high-entertainment value. I might merge this with category 22 in the near future.

**** The Illusionist
****** A Beautiful Mind
****** The Theory of Everything
****** The Imitation Game
***** The Sixth Sense
****** Pi
******* Good Will Hunting
***** The Curious Case of Benjamin Button




-32- American Films with Quick-Witted Protagonists

Very ‘American’ films. Watch these for their quick-witted protagonists, con artists, thieves and coming-of-age themes.

***** The Truman Show
*** Boiler Room
***** Reality Bites
****** Risky Business
**** Rounders
******* Catch Me If You Can
****** Bridge of Spies
**** House of Games
***** Matchstick Men
***** Blow Out




-33- Tim Burton Films

Tim Burton.

***** Nightmare Before Christmas
**** Ed Wood
**** Sweeney Todd




-34- American Gangster and Crime Dramas

American Gangster and crime dramas. Classically entertaining and technically excellent films.

**** Scarface
******* Goodfellas
****** Once Upon a Time in America
******* Godfather I-II
**** Donnie Brasco
****** The Irishman




-35- Beautiful Documentaries on Exotic Phenomena

Beautiful documentaries about exotic phenomena. Watch for intellectual interest.

***** Hubble 3D
****** Helvetica
**** Ant Attack BBC




-36- Avant-Garde Animated Films

Avant-garde animated films with themes of nihilism, psychopathology, and the nature of human existence.

****** Rejected Cartoons
****** Rejected
****** It’s Such a Beautiful Day
****** Everything Will Be OK
***** Salad Fingers
**** Upstream Color
***** The Tree of Life

title: Python in R
text:
library(reticulate)

Create a variable x in the Python session:

x = [1, 2, 3]

Access the Python variable x in an R code chunk:

py$x

[1] 1 2 3


Create a new variable y in the Python session using R, and pass a data frame to y:

py$y <- head(cars)

Print the variable y in Python:

print(y)

{'speed': [4.0, 4.0, 7.0, 7.0, 8.0, 9.0], 'dist': [2.0, 10.0, 4.0, 22.0, 16.0, 10.0]}

title: Mermaid
Mermaid
Gerbich Quick Facts
text:
Summary of Gerbich Blood Group System

Location and Role of Gerbich Antigen:

Found on glycoproteins GPC (glycophorin C) and GPD (glycophorin D), which form a complex with protein 4.1.
Provides mechanical stability to the red blood cell (RBC) membrane.




Gerbich antigens live on glycophorin c and d


Genetics and Structural Variants:

Controlled by the GYPC gene, which has four exons.
High homology between exons 2 and 3 increases the likelihood of crossover events.
Variants in the Gerbich system likely evolved as a selective response to Plasmodium falciparum in malaria-endemic areas.

Phenotypes and Null Variants:

The null phenotype, known as Leach or Gerbich null (Ge: -2,-3,-4), results from the deletion of exons 3 and 4.
Yus phenotype involves deletions in exon 2 and nearby introns; three different alleles are responsible for this type.

Antigens and Antibody Formation:

Main antigens: Ge2, Ge3, Ge4, and GEPL.
Individuals may develop antibodies to Gerbich antigens naturally, through pregnancy, or transfusion. These antibodies can be clinically significant.
Alloimmunization (developing antibodies after exposure to foreign Gerbich antigens) can lead to various outcomes. People with the rare Leach phenotype may form anti-Ge2, anti-Ge3, or anti-Ge4 antibodies.
Autoantibodies to Gerbich antigens, including clinically significant cases causing severe autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA), are documented.

Clinical Associations:

Loss of GPC can lead to transient hereditary elliptocytosis, as the absence of GPC and GPD or protein 4.1 causes hereditary elliptocytosis.
Gerbich 2 can cause hemolysis, while Gerbich 3 can suppress erythropoiesis.
Gerbich variants Ge: -2, -3 are associated with reduced Kell blood group antigens.

title: Cold-Stored Platelet Simulation
text:
Full Code Here:
library(shiny)


Define UI
ui <- fluidPage( titlePanel(“Hospital Inventory Simulation”),
# Preamble section fluidRow( column(12, h3(“Simulation Overview”), p(“This is a simple simulation which models daily average inventory over 365 days for 100 hospitals. Fifty hospitals exclusively receive Cold-Stored Platelets (CSP), and the other fifty exclusively receive Room-Temperature Platelets (RT).”), p(“All patients at all hospitals are identical. However, each patient has a certain daily probability of needing a platelet (defined by a range of minimum to maximum usage probabilities).”), p(“The resulting histograms display the average daily inventory (over a year) for each of the 50 hospitals. This average daily inventory is what we aim to protect and maximize (to an extent).”), strong(“Variables you can tweak:”), tags\(ul(
             tags\)li(“Number of hospitals per condition (default is 50)”), tags\(li("Units each hospital receives daily (constant, default is 1)"),
             tags\)li(“Expiry age for CSP and RT platelets (default: 14 days for CSP and 6 days for RT)”), tags$li(““Cool down period” for CSP and RT platelets: how long patients are ineligible after transfusion (default: 1 day for CSP, 6 days for RT)“) ), p(”One important observation: as the daily probability of patients using a platelet decreases, the inventory levels begin to favor CSP over RT platelets!“) ) ),
sidebarLayout( sidebarPanel( sliderInput(“n_patients”, “Number of Patients per Hospital:”, min = 5, max = 50, value = 10, step = 1), sliderInput(“unitsper_day”, “Units Received per Day:”, min = 1, max = 5, value = 1, step = 1), sliderInput(“expiry_A”, “Expiry Days for Cold-Stored Platelets:”, min = 7, max = 30, value = 14, step = 1), sliderInput(“cooldown_A”, “Cooldown Days for Cold-Stored Platelets:”, min = 0, max = 10, value = 1, step = 1), sliderInput(“cooldown_B”, “Cooldown Days for Room-Temp Platelets:”, min = 0, max = 10, value = 6, step = 1), sliderInput(“min_prob”, “Minimum Usage Probability:”, min = 0.001, max = 0.10, value = 0.10, step = 0.01), sliderInput(“max_prob”, “Maximum Usage Probability:”, min = 0.10, max = 0.50, value = 0.30, step = 0.01) ),
mainPanel( plotOutput(“histogram_CSP”), plotOutput(“histogram_RT”) )
) )


Define Server
server <- function(input, output) {
simulate_hospital <- function(n_patients, n_days, expiry_days, cooldown_days, units_per_day, min_prob, max_prob) { usage_probs <- runif(n_patients, min = min_prob, max = max_prob) next_available_day <- rep(1, n_patients) inventory <- integer(0) daily_inventories <- numeric(n_days)
for(day in seq_len(n_days)) { if (length(inventory) > 0) { inventory <- inventory[inventory > day] }
new_units_expiry <- rep(day + expiry_days, units_per_day) inventory <- c(inventory, new_units_expiry)
eligible_patients <- which(next_available_day <= day) if (length(eligible_patients) > 0 && length(inventory) > 0) { draws <- runif(length(eligible_patients)) used <- draws < usage_probs[eligible_patients]
n_demands <- sum(used)
n_supply <- length(inventory)
n_used <- min(n_demands, n_supply)

if(n_used > 0) {
  user_indices <- eligible_patients[used]
  if (n_demands > n_supply) {
    user_indices <- sample(user_indices, n_used)
  }
  
  for(pat in user_indices) {
    next_available_day[pat] <- day + cooldown_days + 1
  }
  
  inventory <- inventory[seq_len(length(inventory) - n_used)]
}
} daily_inventories[day] <- length(inventory) } mean(daily_inventories)
}
output\(histogram_CSP <- renderPlot({
    avg_inventory_CSP <- replicate(50, simulate_hospital(
      n_patients = input\)n_patients, n_days = 365, expiry_days = input\(expiry_A,
      cooldown_days = input\)cooldown_A, units_per_day = input\(unitsper_day,
      min_prob = input\)min_prob, max_prob = input$max_prob ))
avg_inventory_RT <- replicate(50, simulate_hospital( n_patients = input\(n_patients,
  n_days = 365,
  expiry_days = 6, # Expiry for Room-Temp Platelets is fixed at 6
  cooldown_days = input\)cooldown_B, units_per_day = input\(unitsper_day,
  min_prob = input\)min_prob, max_prob = input$max_prob ))
x_upper <- max(avg_inventory_CSP, avg_inventory_RT)
hist(avg_inventory_CSP, main = “Average Daily Inventory for Cold-Stored Platelets (CSP)”, xlab = “Average Inventory”, xlim = c(0, x_upper), col = “skyblue”, border = “white”)
})
output\(histogram_RT <- renderPlot({
    avg_inventory_CSP <- replicate(50, simulate_hospital(
      n_patients = input\)n_patients, n_days = 365, expiry_days = input\(expiry_A,
      cooldown_days = input\)cooldown_A, units_per_day = input\(unitsper_day,
      min_prob = input\)min_prob, max_prob = input$max_prob ))
avg_inventory_RT <- replicate(50, simulate_hospital( n_patients = input\(n_patients,
  n_days = 365,
  expiry_days = 6, # Expiry for Room-Temp Platelets is fixed at 6
  cooldown_days = input\)cooldown_B, units_per_day = input\(unitsper_day,
  min_prob = input\)min_prob, max_prob = input$max_prob ))
x_upper <- max(avg_inventory_CSP, avg_inventory_RT)
hist(avg_inventory_RT, main = “Average Daily Inventory for Room-Temp Platelets (RT)”, xlab = “Average Inventory”, xlim = c(0, x_upper), col = “tomato”, border = “white”)
}) }


Run the app
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)```

title: Antigen Loss
text:
Did you know that certain antigens can be lost from red cell surfaces?
Here are examples of antigen loss phenomena:

Anti-CD38 Treatment
Treatment with anti-CD38 drugs, such as daratumumab, can cause the loss of CD38 on patient cells over time.
Lewis Antigen Loss During Pregnancy
Lewis a and b antigens can be transiently lost during pregnancy, sometimes leading to the formation of anti-Lewis a/b antibodies.
JMH Antigen Loss in Elderly Patients
Anti-JMH can be lost with advanced age, resulting in the formation of anti-JMH in some elderly patients.
Antigen Loss with Auto- and Allo-antibodies
Antigen loss in the presence of an auto-antibody, and less commonly, allo-antibody, has been described with many blood groups (e.g., Kell).

For a more detailed discussion of this phenomenon, refer to:
PubMed Article: Antigen Loss Phenomena

title: Blood Product Trivia 1
text:
Understanding the technical specifications of blood products is essential for operating blood banks effectively. Here’s a quick guide:



Definition: To label a platelet (Plt) or red blood cell (RBC) component as leukoreduced, it must contain < 5 x 10^6 WBCs, achieved through a filtration process.





Radiation Requirements:

Must receive 25 grays of radiation at the center and >15 grays anywhere in the container.


Shelf Life After Irradiation (Canada):

Maximum: 28 days post-irradiation (but not exceeding the overall maximum shelf life of 42 days).

Example:

If irradiated on Day+5 post-collection, expiry = Day 33.

If irradiated after Day+14, the expiry will remain Day 42 (overall max shelf life).







Definition: Plasma must be frozen within 8 hours of collection to be considered fresh frozen plasma.

Plasma frozen within 24 hours does not qualify as FFP.

Liquid Plasma: A formulation of plasma that is never frozen.





Storage:

Stored at 1–6°C without agitation.

Shelf life: 21 days.


Post-Puncture Use:

If stored above 6°C, must be transfused within 4 hours.

If stored at 1–6°C, must be transfused within 24 hours.


Future Efforts: Research is ongoing to extend the storage period.




These details are operationally critical for blood banks. Learn more here:
FAQ: Whole Blood Leukocytes Reduced (LRWB) - Canadian Blood Services
For more comprehensive guidance, refer to trusted sources like the CBS Professional Education website and AABB Standards. It’s worth keeping a copy and becoming familiar with these resources.

title: Elution
text:
Elution is performed when there is an antibody on red cells which needs to be removed



Acid elution. Negatively charge antigens and antibody, releasing the antibody
Heat elution. Antibody binding is exothermic. When you add heat back in, binding weakens and antibodies are released into the serum
Other methods, such as freeze-thaw, organic solvents, microwave, ultrasound methods, are less common.






Confirming that an antibody found in the patient serum is in fact bound to red cells, in addition (e.g. for allo-antibodies or auto-antibodies)
Removing the antibody to identify its specificity (for allo- or auto-antibodies with specificity)
Removing the antibody so that it won’t interfere with other tests that need to be performed on the red cells, e.g. phenotyping for antigens requiring IAT reagents, such as for litte-s
Removing an antibody which you suspect might be present and causing hemolysis, e.g. an anemic neonate who may have maternal antibodies present on fetal red cells, or, a suspected delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction with antibodies present on transfused red cells
Removing the antibody to concentrate it for further testing, e.g. if initial reactions against panel cells are weak, or for using in a cross-match against potential donor cells (such as for low frequency antigens for which blood units may not be labeled)
Getting clues about drug-related antibodies, which give positive DAT but negative eluate (±negative IAT panel)
As a part of adsorption-elution procedures, which I will not go into here





’Wash red cells thoroughly (e.g. by gently inverting) to remove unbound antibodies and other unbound protein (things just sitting on the red cells), i.e. things which might cause cell non-specific clumping. Washing is typically done 3-4 times using a saline solution.
Collect the fluid from the “last wash” of the red cells. The idea is that this last wash will not contain any unbound gunk (everything should’ve washed away in previous washes). We will use the last wash as a negative control later.
To your washed cells, add acid elution reagent which is usually a low pH buffer. This will cause the antibody to be released from the red cells
Centrifuge the mixture, collect the supernatant/eluate, this should contain any bound antibodies
Neutralize the eluate back to a pH which allows antibody binding to red cells
Centrifuge eluate to remove debris (e.g. broken red cell membranes)
Test the eluate against cells of interest, read off as you would a normal panel
Crucial step: Test the last wash against cells of interest at the same time, which should be negative, showing that the red cells had nothing extra. If it isn’t negative, your eluate isn’t valid because it means there was residual unbound-something on the red cells which could instead explain any observed agglutination, rather than your eluted antibody of interest

For a deeper dive into elution, I suggest the following article by John Judd: Elution

title: Polyagglutination
text:
Definition: Polyagglutination occurs when crypt antigens on red cells are exposed, leading to spontaneous agglutination.

Mechanism:

Crypt antigens are red cell surface glycoproteins to which everyone makes naturally occurring IgM antibodies.
Normally, crypt antigens are unexposed and non-reactive.
When crypt antigens are exposed (via genetic anomalies or RBC surface modifications), universal anti-crypt antigen antibodies bind to them, causing agglutination.

Key Feature: For a patient with exposed crypt antigens, any serum (other than the patient’s own) will cause the patient’s RBCs to agglutinate.
Summary: Polyagglutination is a problem with the patient’s RBCs.

title: Polyagglutination
text:
Panagglutination

Definition: Panagglutination occurs when an autoantibody in the patient’s serum reacts to a universal antigen present on all RBCs, including the patient’s own.
Key Feature: The autoantibody causes pan-reactivity with all RBCs.
Summary: Panagglutination is a problem with the patient’s serum.

title: Polyagglutination
text:
Serology Testing: How They Differ

Panagglutination:

Causes a pan-reactive panel with all donor cells a positive red cellautocontrol.

Polyagglutination:

Causes a pan-reaction with all donor sera (against patient red cells), with a negative serum autocontrol.

title: Polyagglutination
section: Why You Likely Haven’t Seen Polyagglutination
text:
Why You Likely Haven’t Seen Polyagglutination

Polyagglutination would be detectable in tests using patient RBCs (e.g., forward ABO typing or DAT).
Historically, using serum from healthy Type A or B individuals for forward typing would reveal polyagglutination due to universal anti-crypt antigen antibodies
However, in most developed countries, monoclonal antisera is now used for forward typing, containing only anti-A and anti-B antibodies, which prevents the detection of polyagglutination.

title: Polyagglutination
text:
Clinical Relevance of Polyagglutination

Clinical Impact:

Theories suggest polyagglutinating antibodies may cause in vivo hemolysis, particularly in cases of sepsis (e.g., ICU patients with Streptococcus pneumoniae sepsis).
These events are typically complement-mediated hemolysis, resembling or contributing to HUS (Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome).

Diagnosis:

Polyagglutination can be detected by testing patient RBCs against healthy sera.
Hemolysis due to plasma transfusion may indicate polyagglutination.

Management:

Avoid transfusing plasma if polyagglutination and in vivo hemolysis are proven.
This scenario is rare and typically described in case reports.

Further Testing:

A system of lectins exists to identify the specific cause of crypt antigen exposure, whether genetic or acquired.




Additional Resource
For a deeper dive into this phenomenon, read the excellent post on Polyagglutination featured on the CSTM Blog from a few years ago.
